awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Does Calcification By Paleoceanographically Relevant Benthic Foraminifera Provide A Record Of Localized Methane Seepage?
awd_abstract_narration:
Methane occurs in great quantities on continental margins as solid gas hydrates in seafloor sediments. It is also a powerful greenhouse gas that has the potential, when released from sediment-hosted gas hydrates, to dramatically increase global warming. Unfortunately, methane gas hydrates are ephemeral minerals that leave no direct evidence in the rock record. A long-lived indicator of past methane-rich marine environments would be a useful tool for assessing the impact of methane release from marine sediments in the past, which could help us estimate how our presently warming oceans, which can destabilize seafloor methane hydrate deposits and cause them to release their gases, may induce methane gas releases in the future.  This research is focused on exploring the use of the carbon isotopic composition of calcareous tests of tiny sediment-living single-celled organisms called foraminifera (i.e., forams) to realize such a proxy for the occurrence of past seafloor methane seep environments.  This research will study whether foram tests record the seepage of methane by examining whether the calcium carbonate that makes up their tests records the isotopic signature of carbon in methane, which is significantly different from that precipitated from seawater. Broader impacts of the work include the development of teaching units on foraminifera for visually impaired K-12 students at a school in Watertown MA. The curriculum will consist of a multisensory presentation (cold, sound, smell, touch, and heat). It will include 3D models generated by a 3Dprinter from micro-CT scans of foraminifera with known ecology and cell biology. This module will also be included in the curriculum of a local high school in Woods Hole MA and at the Florida Museum of Natural History. 

Goals of the research will be to see if forams calcify their tests in active seep environments and if the signature of the carbon in the seeping methane is recorded in the calcium carbonate the organism deposits. Approximately 40 to 50 forams taken from a 1200 meter deep methane seep site on the Vestnesa Ridge west of Svalbard, Norway will be studied. Multiple cutting-edge analytical techniques will be employed. Individual foram tests will undergo a three-step investigation that consists of (1) micro-computed tomography analysis to determine presence of authigenic carbonate overgrowths, (2) stable isotope mass spectrometry to determine stable carbon isotope values of the calcite, and (3) transmission electron microscopy of the decalcified cell body to establish the organism's viability and adaptation to methane seep habitats via symbionts. Coexisting pore waters from the same sediment cores from which the forams were extracted will be analyzed for inorganic carbon isotopic composition and other geochemical environmental species. Broader impacts of the work include the development of teaching units on foraminifera for visually impaired K-12 students at a school in Watertown MA. The curriculum will consist of a multisensory presentation (cold, sound, smell, touch, and heat). It will include 3D models generated by a 3Dprinter from micro-CT scans of foraminifera with known ecology and cell biology.

por.por_cntn:
Breakdown of methane hydrates due to ocean warming releases methane, a powerful greenhouse gas, to the atmosphere.  Such dissociation of gas hydrates may have led to rapid and dramatic environmental changes in the past. Thus, understanding the impact of those events requires information about their timing and magnitudes.  While the foraminiferal fossil record provides a powerful tool to understand past environmental conditions, seep-endemic foraminifera are unknown, which limits evaluation of seep-specific information.  However, geographically widespread benthic foraminifera do inhabit seep sites, as documented widely in the literature, and may provide information useful to the understanding of past methane releases.  To better understand how benthic foraminifera inhabit this chemosynthesis-based ecosystem, and if they faithfully record the methane emissions, our multidisciplinary collaborative project used a multipronged analysis of foraminifera associated with gas hydrate emission sites in the Arctic. Our goal was to simultaneously assess, in single representative calcareous benthic foraminiferal individuals, the cell biology, test (carbonate ?shell?) stable carbon isotope ratio, and carbonate microstructure (e.g., wall thickness, survey for authigenic overgrowths), from samples collected in two Arctic seepage areas (Vestnesa, west of Svalbard at ~79?N; ~1200-m depth; Storfjordrenna, ~370m water depth).  Serially, each specimen was scanned with microCT (computerized tomography) to assess test characteristics, then the carbonate dissolved by acidification while capturing gas to measure stable carbon isotope ratio via continuous-flow mass spectrometry, and finally the remaining ?soft parts? embedded and examined for cell ultrastructure with a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). 

While we obtained successful microCT scans of seep-associated foraminifera without desiccation and isotopic values of the stable carbon isotope in their calcite tests, our TEM analyses revealed that the ultrastructure of each foraminifer was compromised.  A number of trials were conducted but all attempts to obtain the sequential triple analysis (microCT scan, stable carbon isotope ratio of calcite, and cell structure) failed in that none of the specimens showed unequivocally intact cellular ultrastructure, indicating the specimen was living at the time of fixation. It was not clear if this was because the microCT scanning disrupted the cellular ultrastructure or if the ultrastructure was degrading at the time of collection (i.e., specimens died on the seafloor).  Cellular ultrastructure analyses of foraminifera subject to the triple analyses did reveal, however, that two species living near and in seeps sequestered chloroplasts.  A comparison of the test (calcite) wall thickness showed equivocal results mainly because of low numbers of individuals of the same species from within and outside methane seep sites. Isotope results were also difficult to interpret because the small specimens make those analyses susceptible to CO2 contamination.  Contamination, likely from a preservation reagent, is suspected based on the lack of a relationship between isotope ratios and the specimen mass based on the microCT scans even though comparisons of the specimen mass estimated from the CT scan and mass spectrometry showed a good relationship. These relationships suggest the contaminant had distinctly different isotope ratios, probably isotopically lighter, than expected from the foraminiferal calcite so that minute amounts of contamination disrupted isotope analyses.

Other foraminifera isolated from additional Arctic-seep sediments and analyzed only for their cellular ultrastructure revealed that some foraminifera do inhabit sediments of Arctic hydrocarbon seeps.

 As education/outreach, we developed a teaching module for visually impaired students.  This included 3-D model printed from microCT scans of actual specimens from five different species obtained from vastly different habitats (shallow tropical reef vs deep sea vs Antarctic and Arctic). We presented the module to visually-impaired students twice and sighted students (in a total of six classes). A Powerpoint presentation is included when addressing a sighted audience, who are also encouraged to view the original scanned specimens using light microscopy.
